input: DOCTOR: What brings you in today?\nPATIENT: I'm a 52-year-old woman, and lately I've been feeling really strange. I've had this pounding in my head and sometimes I feel a little dizzy or like things are blurry. My hand has been a bit weak, and I just don't feel right overall, so I thought I should come in and see what’s going on.
output:
THINKING: The patient has introduced new details indicating her age (52 years old), gender (woman), and symptoms including pounding headaches, occasional dizziness, blurry vision, and slight weakness in her hand. These details are new and should be added to the existing vignette.

ANSWER: The patient is a 52-year-old woman presenting with recent symptoms including pounding headaches, occasional dizziness, blurry vision, and slight weakness in her hand.

input:
DOCTOR: What brings you in today?
PATIENT: I'm a 52-year-old woman, and lately I've been feeling really strange. I've had this pounding in my head and sometimes I feel a little dizzy or like things are blurry. My hand has been a bit weak, and I just don't feel right overall, so I thought I should come in and see what’s going on.
DOCTOR: Can you tell me more about how your symptoms have been affecting you—like how often they happen, how long they last, and if anything seems to make them better or worse?
PATIENT: Well, the headaches happen a lot, sometimes I feel them for most of the day, and they don’t seem to go away completely. The nausea comes and goes, and my vision gets a little weird sometimes, especially when the headaches are worse. I haven't really found anything that makes it better, but the headaches just stay kind of constant, you know?
output:
THINKING: The latest conversation confirms that the patient experiences frequent, persistent headaches that last most of the day, with no known relief. She also describes intermittent nausea, occasional blurry vision especially when headaches worsen, and mild hand weakness. These details build upon previous symptoms and specify their frequency and impact. No new symptoms or history have been introduced.  
ANSWER: The patient is a 52-year-old woman presenting with recent symptoms including frequent, persistent headaches lasting most of the day, intermittent nausea, occasional blurry vision during worse headaches, and slight weakness in her hand.

input:
DOCTOR: What brings you in today?
PATIENT: I'm a 52-year-old woman, and lately I've been feeling really strange. I've had this pounding in my head and sometimes I feel a little dizzy or like things are blurry. My hand has been a bit weak, and I just don't feel right overall, so I thought I should come in and see what’s going on.
DOCTOR: Can you tell me more about how your symptoms have been affecting you—like how often they happen, how long they last, and if anything seems to make them better or worse?
PATIENT: Well, the headaches happen a lot, sometimes I feel them for most of the day, and they don’t seem to go away completely. The nausea comes and goes, and my vision gets a little weird sometimes, especially when the headaches are worse. I haven't really found anything that makes it better, but the headaches just stay kind of constant, you know?
DOCTOR: Can you tell me more about how these symptoms have been changing over time and how they’re affecting your daily activities or any other aspects of your life?
PATIENT: Umm, well, at first it was just the headaches, and they would come and go, but lately, they’ve been more persistent and sometimes worse, especially in the right side of my head. The nausea kind of comes and goes too, and I’ve noticed my vision feels off sometimes, like things are blurry or flickering. The left hand thing has been bothering me because I feel a little weaker, and I think it’s been happening more often. It’s kinda hard to do my usual stuff, like cleaning or even just holding things, and I feel a bit tired all the time.
output:
THINKING: The conversation has introduced new specific details about the character and progression of the patient's symptoms, including that her headaches are more persistent and sometimes worse on the right side, and that her hand weakness has been increasing in frequency, affecting daily activities. These details augment the previous vignette with more precise symptom descriptions and their impact. No additional symptoms or history have been mentioned.  
ANSWER: The patient is a 52-year-old woman presenting with recent symptoms including frequent, persistent headaches lasting most of the day, especially on the right side, intermittent nausea, occasional blurry or flickering vision during worse headaches, slight weakness in her left hand which has been happening more often and impacting her daily activities, and she reports feeling tired all the time.
